subject: Planning discussions / emails re. eDialog migration

comments.value:
Hi Jamie,
 
Thank you for your responses. I assume by giving me the links to the signup forms you want me to just take the source code from the pages to get the HTML, is that right?
 
That’s a good point about accessibility and the iframe  – I’ll follow up with Kate/Morag.
 
I will confirm timings for the switchover, but probably worth noting now the absolute latest this new process can go live is 31 August.
 
Andy
 


Andrew McIver | Project Manager | t: 020 3219 6203 | Skype: andrew-mciver
 
From: Jamie Unwin [mailto:jamie@kitsite.com] 
Sent: 05 July 2011 12:43
To: Andrew McIver
Cc: Karlan Shum; Kate Walton; Alastair Greenwood; Morag Reavley; Wahome Muchiri
Subject: RE: Preference Centre
 
Hi Andrew, 
 
My comments are in blue below.
 
I have cc's in Wahome Muchiri [the project manger for the Festival site within the New Media team at LOCOG] as he may be able to answer your questions re signup on Phase II of the festival site.
 
thanks
 
Jamie
 
--
 
Hi Jamie,
 
Please see my comments below in red.
 
Andy
 


Andrew McIver | Project Manager | t: 020 3219 6203 | Skype: andrew-mciver
 


-----Original Message-----
From: Jamie Unwin [mailto:jamie@kitsite.com] 
Sent: 04 July 2011 15:45
To: Kate Walton
Cc: Morag Reavley; Danny Sofer
Subject: Re: Preference Centre

Hi Kate,

"A key date is 10 July, which is when we'll need the creative assets for the iFrame. Essentially that's the HTML builds for the three forms (generic, business, festival). I'm assuming these will come from Kitsite, is that right? They should be able to repurpose the forms they already have in place"

If I understand this requirement correctly we need to create 2 pages similar to this page [ https://www.london2012.com/settings/register.php ] for normal and business signups and one similar to the Festival signup form [http://festival.london2012.com/]. On page load the user should be presented with a box to enter their email address, on submission of this form/email the page should reload with a 'hole' in the middle of it for the iFrame (the contents of which will depend on the form specified and the users email address).Yes, that’s correct.

1) In terms of the standard form(s) (see attached):

Clarification of requirements:

- Two new pages /settings/esignup.php (normal) and /settings/esignupb.php (business) [URL's TBC] both based on the same template using the layout of the exiting register page (header, footer, side nav)
- Design of form for user to enter their email address (based on login form, see attached) As per your mock up, essentially the existing login/signup page with the “Are you already registered with London 2012?” section removed 

OK

- Implementation of functionality to check an email address was correctly entered and display an error message if not. That’s correct, you’ll need to do this. We can supply our java script code for this if that helps?

We already have some server side (and front end) validation code we can use, but thanks for the offer..
 
Although your mentioning of JS validation made me think of accessibility, I know that LOOCG have quite stringent accessibility requirements (which often get picked up at the 11th hour by the ability testing company when it comes to signoff).
 
Kate/Morag: It may be worth checking early on with Ability.net that the use of an iFrame won't cause you to fall short on your accessibility requirements, I know this has happened on a couple of projects recently and meant that work has to be re-though-out / reimplemented just as that work was otherwise about to launch.
 
- Implementation of functionality to convert email entered and page/form used (business or standard) into a eDialog url used to load the iFrame.
- We are expecting only to design the form / functionality for the user to enter their email address and convert this into an eDialog url which we then pull into an iFrame. We are not expecting to be providing creative or markup for the signups form(s) themselves. That’s fine. Can you please supply the HTML for the current forms so we can amend for our iFrame, including any CSS files? Is there any chance you could get this over to us by EOD Thurs?

https://www.london2012.com/settings/register.php
https://www.london2012.com/settings/register.php?reason=businessProfile
Questions:

- What is the maximum height of the iFrame (as we'll need to set this) for the standard and business forms? For normal and business we’ll need to confirm once we’ve re-jigged the forms, but we’ll keep to the existing width – can you please confirm what that is? For festival, we’ll work within the existing dimensions of the box – can you please confirm what these are?

460 px wide for the forms / pages on the main site (see screen grab attached)

- What are the urls for the respective forms / iFrames (ie. how do we convert a users email address / form type into a url for the iFrame) Will need to confirm once our project engineering team has begun the build

OK

2) In terms of the Festival signup form

This is more complex that the above forms as the current signup process / form is not a single step form, click signup square on this form [ http://festival.london2012.com/ ] 

I think there first needs to be a discussion with the Culture team about how these details are reformatted to fit into a single frame,. The Culture team should also be aware that the new form may function differently to the current form (in particular the user journey for users who already have a profile, as I understand it they will be asked to check their email where they will receive a link to the generic eDialog profile manager, rather than being able to signup in situ. Also how any input validation is handled as I expect this may also have to change. I will pick this up with Kate, but yes you’re right, the customer journey will probably have to change here from what it is currently. 

Once that is decided then the Festival site will need to be re-coded to present the user with a email form (this will need a small amount of creative signed off) which doesn't cause the page to reload when submitted (unlike the above forms) after that the process of loading the iFrame should be very similar to the mechanism used above for the standard and business forms.

Im not sure of exact timescales, but the Festival site is due to re-lauch this summer in a Phase II format. It may therefore make more sense to focus on at implementing the eDialog style forms into that version of the festival site (where you can have early input in the design / signup process) rather than trying to shoe-horn an eDialog/iFrame style sign form in place of the current multi step form. Does the area where the iframe will sit have different dimensions when phase II is launched? If so, then makes sense for us to develop with phase II in mind.

I would expect it to be different, it is a much larger site, but AFAIK design work hasn't even started - we are not involved with the design, probably best if Kate (or Morag) speak with the Culture team and/or Wahome Muchiri [the project manger for the Festival site within the New Media team at LOCOG] who I have cc'd in) 

== Timescales 

In terms of timescales (for part 1, the standard forms) we could centrally create a 'test' page (on the live or staging server) with a iFrame and a fixed url for the 10th (so that eDialog) could test the iFrame in situ *although* we would need another week (15th July) to implement the email signup box and to dynamically create the urls used to pull a page from eDialog into the iFrame. That’s fine.

In terms of switch over, do you have a time you are expecting to swap over as we'll need to work out a migartion strategy to re-map the old signup / register urls to the new page.

thanks
 
Jamie
 
Before committing to creating or updating the festival site (part 2). I think (if you haven't already done so) it may make sense to see how your timelines and the festival timelines overlap with regards to the Phase II site and then decide if it makes more sense to implement the eDialog signup functionality into that Phase II site (at the design stage) rather than trying to re-factor the current site (as I expect there will be small but non inconsequential implementation / refactoring issues here).

Jamie

A company registered in England and Wales with its registered office at One Churchill Place, Canary Wharf, London E14 5LN and registered number 05267819

subject: Generation of News XML sitemap (was a general all sitemaps)

comments.value: We would like to generate and publish xml sitemaps, including specific photo and video sitemaps, as discussed on the recent SEO call.  Raising ticket to track queries and progress.
Marked as High.

Following the successful URL optimisation rollout this is our new top SEO priority. I see that photos already have a sitemap - we need one for contact pages, news stories and videos as well.  Also, could you confirm how often the photos one gets republished?  Is it everytime we publish a new image?

Additional information from David Marshall:

When implementing the news specific sitemap schema for London2012.com please follow the Google spec http://www.google.com/support/webmasters/bin/answer.py?hl=en&answer=74288

It is important that this news sitemap be updated as soon as news articles are published and that this specific news sitemap only contain articles published in the last 48 hours. All articles can be included in the global sitemap but this news specific sitemap should be a subset of the ones published in the last 48 hours. Executing this properly will provide significantly greater reach for your news through google news.

Also, upon publishing a news article on London2012.com we need to PIng google and let them know your sitemap has been updated. So upon publishing a news article the CMS should:
1. Update the news specific sitemap
2. Ping Google with an http request for your sitemap URL telling them it has been updated (e.g. www.google.com%2Fwebmasters%2Ftools%2Fping%3Fsitemap%3Dwww.london2012.com%2Fsitemap_news if your news sitemap file is called sitemap_news and located in your root directory)

I just spoke to Andy about this one. This is his top priority SEO task. Provisionally, I have suggested that we will look at this next week, but let's review the workload again on Monday and I will give him an update then.
A clarification - we should ping google to alert of a new sitemap any time new content is published - not just when new news stories are published.

Hi Andy,

We now have a new sitemap.

News site map (currently showing last 30 days, will only show news form yesterday and today once live)
http://www.london2012.com/news-sitemap.xml

Can push it over to Google tomorrow once we are happy with it / let them know to expect it as a news source (if you haven't' yet done so)
http://www.google.com/support/webmasters/bin/answer.py?answer=74289

It seems to validate fine
http://www.validome.org/google/

We also coded a few look up tables to try and map CMS/LOCOG/ODA tags to Google keywords for Sports and Culture where possible (ie. Football maps to Soccer)
http://www.google.com/support/news_pub/bin/answer.py?answer=116037

We have not yet setup any automated ping mechanism, I assume we want to use the same mechanism for the main site map (which we're also yet to to start)

[as mentioned on the phone the biggest issue here is making sure we don't send pages that should be hidden, I expect that would be far more of an issue than making Google aware of the few dozen pages that  may currently be getting missed due to lack of a site map. We're hopefully going to get onto mapping out some logic / mechanism for deciding which pages to send or exclude early next week. Once we have that logic in place the site map itself should be fairly easy to code. Although we may need to split it out  over several sitemaps so as not to hit the 50,000 pages limit for a single sitemap file]

In answer to your question re. the Image site map, this is currently generated daily.
http://www.london2012.com/sitemap-images.xml

Jamie

Hi Jamie,

Has this been unpublished? I just get a 404 when I take a look.

Cheers,
Andy

Sorry wrong url, try this..
http://www.london2012.com/sitemap-news.xml

Looks good. Is it possible to specify the date and time that the article was published, rather than just the date? Google news appears to order articles by age, so having an accurate publish time ought to help if they accept us as a valid news source.

Hi Andy,

We can only specify one date and the editorial 'publication' date (postDate) doesn't have a time component.
http://www.google.com/support/webmasters/bin/answer.py?hl=en&answer=74288&from=42738&rd=1

The first publication date (firstPublicationDate) has a time component, but it isn't always the same as the editorial 'publication' date.

We did once try to do a composite of the two ie. take the date component from from 'postDate' field and the time component from the 'firstPublicationDate' attribute. I can't remember the exact issues but I do remember that it resulted in everyone getting really confused.

Jamie

Hi Jamie,

Thanks for the explanation; sounds like we should stick with what you’ve already implemented. Can you limit the sitemap to articles from the last 48 hours and push live? I haven’t registered it with Google yet – I’ll wait until you’ve confirmed it’s published.

Also, just so I’m clear, can you confirm that the file will republish every time we publish a new news story?

Cheers,
Andy

Hi Andy,

Updated to show only the last 48 hrs (it's actually all articles from yesterday and today) and to republish whenever a news story is published.

Jamie

Hi Jamie,

Have you guys had a chance to think about how to generate the regular content sitemap and video sitemap XML files? With regards to general content, I know you were concerned about including pages that aren't in the navigation. I think the way to do this is to exclude any pages that are hidden from navigation, or not published. Everything else should already be on the site and accessible to Google so the rule should work - I think!

Cheers,
Andy

Hi Andy,

In short we can get started on this next week, you may want to read down for the issues/thought we have (some of these are just internal notes / aide memoires)

1) Video sitemap is straightforward, will schedule in for early next week. 

2) General sitemap, a couple things we need to deal with, which make it tricker than just looking though all the page son the site and outputting an XML file.

a) Excluding pages that are in the CMS but aren't normally navigable to. As you say everything that does not have 'hide from navigation' should appear, but it's not quite as simple as we do have pages that are excluded by section for example signup pages and test directories. 

Probably the best thing here is for us to create the site map and then have a run though it and see if we can spot any pages that shouldn't be in it.

b) Splitting the files out into multiple files to get round the Google limit of 5000 pages, not an issue per sea but need to do a few queries to work out who to split the site up , probably best if we separate out the sections with large amounts of content, ie. news, images, suppliers and then leave another file with just standard 'content' pages. 

Will run some counts of the top sections to work out where to split.

c) Updates, once again not an issue per sea. but we've been discussing internally how best to handle this in the CMS as generating a site map for the whole site each day (or more frequently) is fairly processor heavy. 

We can start with a new sitemap generated at say 2am each night.

d) "Virtual hub pages" this is a very interesting one, especially as we're about to relaunch the News section using this format/method. By "Virtual hub pages" I mean hub pages (ie. "Culture News") that don't actually exist in he CMS but are instead created 'on the fly' via a url such as "london2012.com/news?tag=culture" or london2012.com/photos?tag=culture". Currently Google will find these pages via it's crawler, so there is no issue. But once we switch to using a sitemap there seems to be consensus (via a bit of googling) that results from crawling can drop once you are actively serving a site map (I expect Larry Page n isn't even sure and that half of this stuff is old wives tales / speculation).

I think Danny/Kieran have already proposed some work/costs as an extension to the SEO work (copying Danny/Kieran in on this response) to store these urls in the CMS, so that you could link to /news/culture in the CMS but that would actually be mapped to /news?tag=culture. If we did this then we'd have a list of all those 'psudo hub pages' and could export them in the sitemap.

In the immediate term, I assume we'll just have to live without them and hope Google doesn't start to drop the hub pages for given topics (ie. Culture News). In the medium term, if we haven't completed the work above, I guess we could hardcode a sitemap of urls for the key 'pseudo hub pages'.
Just republishing the pages (without the counter) now..

Hi Andy,

In short we can get started on this next week, you may want to read down for the issues/thought we have (some of these are just internal notes / aide memoires)

1) Video sitemap is straightforward, will schedule in for early next week.

2) General sitemap, a couple things we need to deal with, which make it tricker than just looking though all the page son the site and outputting an XML file.

a) Excluding pages that are in the CMS but aren't normally navigable to. As you say everything that does not have 'hide from navigation' should appear, but it's not quite as simple as we do have pages that are excluded by section for example signup pages and test directories.

Probably the best thing here is for us to create the site map and then have a run though it and see if we can spot any pages that shouldn't be in it.

b) Splitting the files out into multiple files to get round the Google limit of 5000 pages, not an issue per sea but need to do a few queries to work out who to split the site up , probably best if we separate out the sections with large amounts of content, ie. news, images, suppliers and then leave another file with just standard 'content' pages.

Will run some counts of the top sections to work out where to split.

c) Updates, once again not an issue per sea. but we've been discussing internally how best to handle this in the CMS as generating a site map for the whole site each day (or more frequently) is fairly processor heavy.

I think Danny/Kieran have already proposed some work/costs as an extension to the SEO work (copying Danny/Kieran in on this response) to store these urls in the CMS, so that you could link to /news/culture in the CMS but that would actually be mapped to /news?tag=culture. If we did this then we'd have a list of all those 'psudo hub pages' and could export them in the sitemap.

In the immediate term, I assume we'll just have to live without them and hope Google doesn't start to drop the hub pages for given topics (ie. Culture News). In the medium term, if we haven't completed the work above, I guess we could hardcode a sitemap of urls for the key 'pseudo hub pages'.

Hi Liz,
Are they definitely choosing "utf-8" as the character set when opening the
csv export?
Kieran

My guess is they aren't being prompted to choose -- do you off-hand know how to change the setting in excel (which is what they're definitely using to open the CSV)?

________________________________

Hi Liz,

We'll take a look at this, 

It's not a bug per sea, the characters are actually correct (if you look at the file in a text editor or web page you'll see they are correct). The problem is Excel is trying to display it using the incorrect character set. We (like 99.9% of the web and products) use UTF-8 as it's standard compliment. Microsoft for some reason likes to use their own character encoding and worse still refuses to automatically open UTF-8 docs as UTF-8

We are not alone in this issue, Google is full of pages people discussing this issue, with no clear solution (at least none without other issues).
http://www.myintervals.com/forum/discussion/280/making-csv-data-exports-with-utf8-more-excel-friendly/

We are outputting a completely valid UTF-8 .csv file the issue is Excel won't respect the character set.

The problem is that in order to get Excel to support UTF-8 CSV we have to change it to a TSV (tab separated) file and charge the charset to a superset of UTF-8 called UTF-16 Little Endian. But when you do that all your multiline content is stripped of line breaks.

What can we / you do?

- We can try and translate those chars, mainly MS curly quotes into normal quotes that will work in any western charset (this will initially give the impression that we have fixed the problem and is probably what most people do, but it this won't fix all characters, but will fix the worst offenders) 
- We can output a TSV file and charge the charset to UTF-16 (this is what Google docs do as is more correct than the above, but you will lose line breaks in multi line text)
- We can export XML ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SpreadsheetML ) which new versions of Excel will import instead (but you will need a newer version of Excel to open it; this is probably the cleanest way to fix the issue)
- I think in the past we used a trick of setting the first few char in the document to a UTF-8 instruction code, this kind of wakes Excel up to the fact it's really an UTF-8 doc (going to refresh myself on this / see if it still works in newer versions of Excel)

Obviously if your editing the file in Excel then *this is an issue* but just wanted to point out that there is no 'quick fix' (that wont' have other consequences) we will however have a think about which if the above solutions is the lesser evil and get back to you.

Jamie

* not much consolation, but if you open it in Google docs it will appear correctly, I'm not sure how much Google Docs handle the export to Excel (I expect they will have developed or licensed some expensive Excel import/export libraries)

If you set the charset encoding of the web page to utf-8, and then Response. BinaryWrite the UTF-8 Byte Order Mark (0xEF 0xBB 0xBF) at the top of the csv file, then Excel 2007 (not sure about other versions) will recognize it as utf-8 and open it correctly.

http://www.myintervals.com/forum/discussion/280/making-csv-data-exports-with-utf8-more-excel-friendly/

The OW team use the export for reporting, and I think they do sometimes copy/paste text out of there for use. I can ask them if they'd be comfortable using google docs, but I suspect the exporting XML might be the easiest fix. (i actually think we've got office 2010 at work - but i'm home now so i can check tomorrow)

subject: Refactor registration workflow

comments.value:
Work already completed: 6 days
* Make amendments to the Community library (the frontend php library) to facilitate the simpler registration procedure (double-opt-in, but
no password requirement).
* Make amendments to the CMS to facilitate the above
* Created a dev test site, and implemented some html/php in order to test the above.
* Extensive testing on dev.
* Amended the live 2012 landing page (where you end up when you click on your validation email) in order to work with the above functionality.

Still to do: 4 days approx
* Write a feed to send emails to people who amend their details ("You recently logged in and changed your details, we're just checking that you really meant to do this").
* Further testing and inevitable tweaks.

I raised this with Danny last week but just wanted to put something on record:

There is likely to be a change of plan with the registration process since our last conversation. In order to accommodate the additional 4m records from Ticketing, Kate has decided that she wants to bring forward the use of eDialog preference centre to serve as the main sign-up / preference management centre on london2012.com.

Instead of London2012.com hosting sign-up / user management, we would host an iframe / link to the eDialog preference centre (skinned to look like our site).  A diagram is attached which shows how all the databases interrelate.

There are a number of implications for us, some of which are summarised below:

1. We need to review phase 2 of our planned registration refactoring, as much of this will now not be required. Principally the intention is not to ask eDialog to reintegrate with the modified data feed, so that they can focus on setting up the preference centre (which probably won't be ready until September). This means that we need to do manual exports of unsubscribe / subscribe deltas in order to allow us to continue to conduct email campaigns. We will probably also hold fire on data purging from our system. 

2. The removal of a UMS from our system means that we won't be able to support any other logged in functionality - most notably commenting on blogs. I will talk to colleagues to find out how big a deal this is but I suspect not very. Please can you think about other ways in which we could approve commenting without a sign-in feature. The other possible area of functionality which we can't now support would be the mooted Festival 'favourites' list - but I don't think this was a very key feature.

3. If we are moving to eDialog for sign-ups / preference management, we need to think about how this impacts the Festival sign-up and TAB sign-up pages.

Can you think of any other consequences / implications we need to consider?

Kate is currently on leave but I suggest a call with her and eDialog on her return would be advisable. I just wanted to let you know now before we get too far down executing the rest of the registration changes we have discussed.

Have unassigned this ticket from me.
The best course of action is probably to:
  1. Split Morag's new comment into a new ticket.
  2. Close this ticket (#4271)

We still need to check the double opt-in with no password is working on Festival and then, after getting approval from Morag, implement it on the main site. This work has a budget of 10 days total. Reassigned back to you, Kieran.

Morag, the refactoring of registration to allow double opt-in without password setting; to include email updates whenever there is a change to a profile; and to allow additions to preferences and mailing lists without authentication is now complete and functioning on the Festival site. If you are happy with the way it is now working then all we need to do is switch on double opt-in with no passwords for all new users, not just festival signups.

Just say the word and we will switch it on.
If we do this, what is the solution to allowing blog commenting?
Morag, can I just check what we are going to do about blog commenting after the switch to e-dialog?

See #4528. 

Morag, I am going to mark this as solved for now, but if you do want us to remove the requirement to enter a password on the main site before switching over to e-dialog, just let us know and we will do it.

comments.value:
---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Andy Watkins <Andy.Watkins@london2012.com>
Date: 27 June 2011 09:37
Subject: FW: Tender Documentation for New Online Map
To: Danny Sofer <danny@kitsite.com>, Jamie Unwin <jamie@kitsite.com>


Hi Danny/Jamie,



We are planning on running a tender to procure a new map provider.
I’ve sent the attached brief round for internal review but would also
appreciate your input. Are you able to provide feedback as tracked
changed and comments by COB tomorrow?



Do please treat this confidentially – i.e. don’t discuss with Stamen
if you’re in touch with them for any other reason – we haven’t yet
broached the subject with them.



Regards,

Andy


From: Andy Watkins
Sent: 24 June 2011 14:53
To: Julie Dark; Wahome Muchiri; Deborah Hale; Jemma Thompson; Kika
Dabbs; Paul Bunnell; Aaron Shone; David Finch; Russ Ede
Cc: Alex Balfour; Liz Goulding; Morag Reavley; Nicola Peers; Davina
Green; #LOCOG New Media
Subject: Tender Documentation for New Online Map

All,

For a number of reasons we have decided to replace the current
interactive map on the London 2012 website. A new mapping solution
will be procured that will replicate much of the functionality of the
existing map but also introduce new functionality required to support
critical campaigns such as Torch Relay and Festival 2012.

Attached is the draft ITT. Could I ask you all to review the sections
pertinent to your area of responsibility and send me any questions and
tracked feedback by close of business Tuesday, 28 June. Please also
send me contact details of any companies you would like to invite to
take part in this tender.

The plan is to publish a PQQ to CompeteFor next week to get the ball
rolling. Critical delivery dates are October for the Festival 2012
ticketing announcement, and November for the OTR route announcement.

In terms of funding, it is our expectation that FAs requiring specific
new functionality will fund development of that functionality, and
that replication of existing functionality will be met by New Media.

At the moment our plan is to leave the existing map on the Get Set and
PGTC websites, although this may need to be reviewed in light of
recent developments.

Nicola and Davina from Procurement, cc’d above, are kindly supporting
this procurement process and will lead on bidder liaison.

If you believe it would be useful to have a meeting to walk through
this document do please let me know.

Regards,

Andy



Andy Watkins
Setting to high.
Danny - have you been able to review this yet?
We have indeed. Jamie is looking at it again now and I expect he will be in touch shortly.

Hi Andy,

Find attached a copt of your doc with my comments.

Happy to have a quick chat if you have any other questions

Jamie
Attached again with slightly less typos !

Hi Andy,

Though I'd jot this down the two approaches (see attached route 1 and 2) to integrating with the map server, including what we do currently (easier that trying to describe it over the phone!).

In terms of the map server not having it's own db and using external db in real time, this is technical no no for multiple reasons (performance, how location baed data needs to be stored so you can do nearest lookups etc. not to mention that the map relying on multiple 3rd parties would be project management hell!). 

Although you probably do want to give some though as to how much data the map server needs to store especially given that there may well be a delay in editorial changes to pages and them being updated on the map. For example you may prefer it to keep a 'light' record (name, desc, type, date, postcode, geocode in the map DB) but retrieve further more detailed content in real time. Especially with the more esoteric kinds of content you may want to display.

Jamie
Jamie: still 0.2 days?
+2hrs phone call and further docs explaining the API integration (although to be fair Andy didn't explicitly ask for docs)

subject: A reusable script for changing links to external sites

comments.value: Occasionally external URLs that are linked from several pages change, causing them all to break. How much effort would it be to create a script that could be run to change them all at once, as and when needed (without it taking Kitsite more than 30 mins or so). Or alternatively is this simple enough that it could be done ad hoc in under an hour or so?

I could develop something, and document it. Running it on an ad hoc basis would - as you suggest - take about 1/2 hour.
It would prob take at least 0.5 day to develop, possibly more. I've just had a brief stab at writing such a script, and quickly encountered one or two gotchas.
Can document them here - if required?
Note to Kieran: see /mnt/shared/Kitsite/London2012/Tickets/2231.txt
Liz, awaiting your approval.
Sorry, Kieran, what are you documenting? The trouble is that if it’s a half day, we should probably do it, but if you’re confident it will be more I don’t think it’s worth it for right now...
Hi, Just to follow on from this as Liz is away: Kieran can I check how much of your time this would take? If it will be half a day I'd be happy to go ahead with this. Cheers. Zara

Hello, In order to ensure that this works "properly", it would take us 1 day to develop it, and then less than 45 mins to run, each time you wanted a url replaced. I estimated 1/2 day, but then - once I started looking at it - there were some gotchas I encountered, so I'll need to up the estimate to 1 day.
It is not quite as simple as doing a find-and-replace, replacing all instances of
  http://www.example.com/path
with
  http://www.example.com/new-path
because - for example - there might be some occurrences of:
  http://www.example.com/path/path2
which - unless I add some extra processing - will be replaced with:
  http://www.example.com/new-path/path2
which may or may not be correct.
Basically I will add the option of doing either type of replacement.

Hi Kieran,

Please don't do it now, then. We'll do the encountered problem ourselves, now, and if it occurs again perhaps rethink!

Happy New Year!

Liz
________________________________
danny, as per our discussion, have set actual days = 0.2, in recognition of the time that I spent investigating the issue.
Liz, Kieran has already spent an hour or so investigating this. Should we close the ticket or can I twist your arm to let him do the work?
Marking as solved.

Morag, we have actually set things up now so that you can do splash pages without us, but 6pm should be fine.
Oho! Do I know this? I may well do but brain is still in post-holiday recuperative mode and have probably forgotten.

Here are the instructions:

1) Edit this page (http://new2012.kitsite.com/kit/pages/edit/includes/homepage-takeover.php) in the CMS.
2) There is a hyperlink container named "splashPage". Whatever this fragment links to will become the "splash page". i.e. you should use the "link" tool to pick the whatever page or asset you want the splash page to be. NB It can even be a link to an external website (just enter the url into the link picker).
3) Once you've chosen the splash destination, save and publish includes/homepage-takeover.php.
4) As soon as this page goes live, the homepage will redirect to the splash page.

To remove the splash page redirect:
1) edit the page again in the CMS (http://new2012.kitsite.com/kit/pages/edit/includes/homepage-takeover.php) and use the (X) tool to remove the link assigned to the "splashPage" container.
2) Publish includes/homepage-takeover.php. Once it is live, the homepage takeover will disappear.

We will be on hand to provide assistance or if you want it on staging first, we can turn off syncing, so that you can test it all works before it goes live.
